tossups.question: Mixologist Dave Arnold has created a noted cocktail utilising this plant. This green plant is used in the Jiangxi (“jang-SHEE”) dish sānbēijī (“san-bay-jee”). Sharbats or Faloodas may often include the seeds of this plant which are soaked in water until they resemble frogspawn. Larousse Gastronomique (“la-ROOSE ga-stro-no-MEEK”) describes how this plant’s name comes from the Greek for "royal" as only the king was allowed to cut it. This plant, known as kaphrao (“ka-prao”) in (*) Thai, is stir-fried and added to drunken chicken. This plant’s “holy” variety is referred to as tulsi in India. This plant is blended with garlic to make a paste which flavours the Provençal (“pro-von-SAWL”) soup pistou (“PEE-stoo”) and this plant accompanies mozzarella and tomatoes in a traditional Caprese (“ca-PRAY-zay”) salad. For 10 points, what herb’s leaves provide the traditional green colour of pesto?
tossups.question_sanitized: Mixologist Dave Arnold has created a noted cocktail utilising this plant. This green plant is used in the Jiangxi (“jang-SHEE”) dish sānbēijī (“san-bay-jee”). Sharbats or Faloodas may often include the seeds of this plant which are soaked in water until they resemble frogspawn. Larousse Gastronomique (“la-ROOSE ga-stro-no-MEEK”) describes how this plant’s name comes from the Greek for "royal" as only the king was allowed to cut it. This plant, known as kaphrao (“ka-prao”) in (*) Thai, is stir-fried and added to drunken chicken. This plant’s “holy” variety is referred to as tulsi in India. This plant is blended with garlic to make a paste which flavours the Provençal (“pro-von-SAWL”) soup pistou (“PEE-stoo”) and this plant accompanies mozzarella and tomatoes in a traditional Caprese (“ca-PRAY-zay”) salad. For 10 points, what herb’s leaves provide the traditional green colour of pesto?

tossups.question: David Schramm’s plot of mass fractions is used to visualize this event’s “lithium problem”. Soviet study of this event went unnoticed for a decade until Arthur Walker and Howard Robinson rigorously proved the properties of Alexander Friedmann’ model. Ralph Alpher was annoyed for at least 50 years that his adviser, George Gamow (“GAM-mov”), added Hans Bethe (“BAY-teh”) as a co-author in absentia on a pivotal paper about this event. An inflaton (“in-FLAY-ton”) field may have influenced the period immediately following this event, which was first proposed by Catholic priest Georges (*) Lemaître (“george le-MET-truh”). The separation of the fundamental forces after this event defines several epochs (“epics”), which begin with a short one named for Planck ("plonk"). This event is a logical necessity of an expanding universe. For 10 points, name this event believed to have occurred 13.8 billion years ago, creating space and time.
tossups.answer: the Big Bang [accept Big Bang nucleosynthesis; prompt on BBN; prompt on the creation of the universe before mentioned; prompt on inflation or recombination with “what event does that follow?”]

Wim Wenders's (“vim venders’”) The Wrong Move is an adaptation of a novel by this person. Many Latin American flags are primary colors because of a conversation Francisco de Miranda had with this person. A Charles (*) Gounod ("GOO-noh") opera based on a play by this person was sometimes premiered as Margarethe (“mar-ga-RAY-teh”) out of respect for this person's work. In the book of Ezekiel, a reference is made to a tradition of rubbing new-born babies with this substance. In the Sermon on the Mount, Jesus follows a phrase describing the disciples as this substance with one describing the “light of the world”. (*) Ado (“AH-doe”) is a traditional name given to a person associated with this substance, who disobeyed an instruction from angels not to look back at the city of Sodom. tossups.question: This man served as comptroller of London’s port for 12 years, an unusually long time. This man was captured at the unsuccessful siege of Reims (“reems”), after which he served as a messenger to the king during negotiations. This man wrote a treatise on using the astrolabe for his son Lewis. This man probably attended the wedding of Lionel of Antwerp and Violante (“vee-o-LAN-tay”) Visconti where he may have met Froissart (“fwa-SAR”) and (*) Bocaccio (“bo-KAH-chee-oh”). tossups.question: This character discusses her own “hideous transformation” in a room supposedly haunted by Jack Straw and Peter Ochello, whose relationship had a “tenderness which was uncommon.” A man fends off this character’s sexual advances by using a chair as if he were a lion tamer. This character calls her sister-in-law a “monster of fertility” who has given birth to five “no-neck monsters.” At the end of a play, this character professes her love for her husband, to which he responds (*) “wouldn’t it be funny if that were true?” In order to secure an inheritance, this character tells Big Mama that she is pregnant. This character believes that her husband is gay due to his extremely close relationship with his football buddy, Skipper. For 10 points, name this woman whose husband Brick leaves her sexually frustrated in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.
tossups.answer: Maggie Pollitt [or Margaret Pollitt or Maggie the Cat; prompt on Pollitt; prompt on Cat on a Hot Tin Roof before mention]

An arrangement for cello with piano accompaniment is the only part of this composer’s most famous work that he allowed to be played publicly before his death. Zygmunt Stojowski (“ZIG-munt sto-YOV-ski”) joked that this composer’s second piano concerto “begins with Bach and ends with Offenbach.” This composer imitated his own Danse macabre (“DONS ma-COB”) by using xylophones to imitate clattering bones in a movement that quotes Twinkle Twinkle Little Star. tossups.question: The concept “author of [this work]” is used in the article on Frege’s (“FRAY-geh’s”) theorem in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy in order to explain Hume’s principle. In his autobiography, Herbert A. Simon described designing IPL in order to reproduce proofs from this work. This work uses a “ramified theory of types” in order to avoid a paradox concerning (*) sets that do not contain themselves. A response to this work contains Gödel’s (“girdle’s”) incompleteness theorems. This work ventures to prove the Peano (“pee-AW-no”) axioms using first-order logic, and after about 350 pages of groundwork, it finally proves that 1 plus 1 equals 2. For 10 points, name this philosophical work that sets out to resolve mathematical paradoxes, written by Alfred North Whitehead and Bertrand Russell.
tossups.answer: the Principia Mathematica [accept the PM; do not accept or prompt on “the Principia”]

tossups.question: Baire (“bare”) class 1 functions are constructed by performing this operation on a sequence of Baire class 0 functions. The use of this operation defines standard analysis, as opposed to nonstandard analysis which uses hyperreal numbers. The superior and inferior forms of this operation are used to quickly prove the squeeze theorem, which is an intuitive way to evaluate this operation. In analysis, this operation is defined in terms of (*) deltas and epsilons. This operation is performed on a Riemann (“REE-monn”) sum in the definition of the Riemann integral. For 10 points, name this operation that finds the value a function’s output approaches as its input approaches a number.

tossups.question: This quantity is imaginary in a tachyonic (“tacky-ON-ic”) field. Fermions without this property are described by the Weyl (“vile”) equation, which can be used to model the movement of electrons in graphene. The SI unit for this quantity is derived using Planck’s (“plonk’s”) constant to measure the current in the coils of a mechanism named for Bryan Kibble. It’s not energy, but when using natural units such that the speed of light is 1, this quantity can be measured in (*) electron-volts. This quantity has a negligible impact on a particle’s energy at the ultra-relativistic limit. The equivalence principle equates this quantity’s inertial variant with its gravitational variant. The Higgs boson gives some particles, for 10 points, what quantity whose SI unit is the kilogram?
tossups.question_sanitized: This quantity is imaginary in a tachyonic (“tacky-ON-ic”) field. Fermions without this property are described by the Weyl (“vile”) equation, which can be used to model the movement of electrons in graphene. The SI unit for this quantity is derived using Planck’s (“plonk’s”) constant to measure the current in the coils of a mechanism named for Bryan Kibble. It’s not energy, but when using natural units such that the speed of light is 1, this quantity can be measured in (*) electron-volts. This quantity has a negligible impact on a particle’s energy at the ultra-relativistic limit. The equivalence principle equates this quantity’s inertial variant with its gravitational variant. The Higgs boson gives some particles, for 10 points, what quantity whose SI unit is the kilogram?
tossups.answer_sanitized: mass [accept rest mass, inertial mass, gravitational mass]

A novel by this author is co-dedicated to their Bennington College contemporary Bret Easton Ellis and begins with a prologue which describes “one of the biggest (*) manhunts in Vermont history”. Richard Papen describes how Bunny Corcoran came to die in this author’s debut novel. A novel by this author of The Little Friend details how Theodore survives a bombing at the Met where he rescues a small painting by Carel Fabritius. For 10 points, name this author of The Secret History and The Goldfinch.

tossups.question: A player with this unusual nickname beat Chuck McKinley and Martin Mulligan in consecutive Wimbledon finals each lasting less than an hour. Bernie Geoffrion (“joff-re-ON”) was booed for winning the scoring title when he denied a teammate with this nickname. A player with this nickname was suspended by Clarence Campbell for hitting an official during the 1955 (*) Stanley Cup, prompting a riot which presaged Quebec’s Quiet Revolution. A snooker player with this unusual nickname won his sixth World Championship by beating Kyren Wilson in 2020. For 10 points, several players with the first names Roger, Rod or Ronnie have been given what "explosive" nickname given to Maurice Richard (“ri-SHARD”)?
tossups.answer: the Rocket [accept Rocket Rod Laver, Rocket Richard, or Ronnie the Rocket O’Sullivan; prompt on Rod or Ronnie with “what other nickname does he have?”]
tossups.question_sanitized: A player with this unusual nickname beat Chuck McKinley and Martin Mulligan in consecutive Wimbledon finals each lasting less than an hour. Bernie Geoffrion (“joff-re-ON”) was booed for winning the scoring title when he denied a teammate with this nickname. A player with this nickname was suspended by Clarence Campbell for hitting an official during the 1955 (*) Stanley Cup, prompting a riot which presaged Quebec’s Quiet Revolution. A snooker player with this unusual nickname won his sixth World Championship by beating Kyren Wilson in 2020. For 10 points, several players with the first names Roger, Rod or Ronnie have been given what "explosive" nickname given to Maurice Richard (“ri-SHARD”)?
tossups.answer_sanitized: the Rocket [accept Rocket Rod Laver, Rocket Richard, or Ronnie the Rocket O’Sullivan; prompt on Rod or Ronnie with “what other nickname does he have?”]

bonuses.leadin: Raschig Super-Rings and Fenske helices (“FEN-skee HEE-li-sees”) are used to increase the surface area available to these components. For 10 points each:
answers: plates [or trays; accept packed beds or theoretical plates; prompt on columns] (The McCabe-Thiele method is being described.)
liquid AND gas [accept liquid-gas interface; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these components, which are often irregular and disperse rather than flat. A graphical method of predicting the number of these components draws a staircase between a triangular region and an equilibrium curve.

Each plate is a place where these two phases of matter can coexist. Distillation separates a mixture in one of these phases by heating it up, causing part of it to evaporate into the other phase. Name both.

Water-cooled sleeves condense vapor and trickle it back into the column as part of this technique, which improves the efficiency of a distillation. This technique can maintain a closed loop when the reaction vessel is maintained above the boiling point.

bonuses.leadin: This university was upset by the Chaminade (“shah-mi-nod”) Silverswords in 1982 in what was then dubbed the biggest upset of all time. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this college basketball team who were led to their first NCAA title by DeAndre Hunter in 2019, a year after becoming the first men's 1 seed to lose to a 16 seed when they lost to UMBC.

This NBA coach started in the back court for Virginia in the 1982 loss to Chaminade. This man’s surname is also the name of the English town whose football club became the first former First Division team to be relegated from the EFL.
Beating Virginia paved the way for Chaminade to annually host the Maui Invitational in this state.

bonuses.leadin: One of these body parts is boiled, then stomped on in order to remove its fat. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this body part which titles a short story about Zenchi Naigu, published in a Tokyo Imperial University student magazine.
Another short story called “The Nose” is by this Russian surrealist who also wrote “The Overcoat.”
This character from Midnight’s Children has a large, bulbous nose that is always dripping. He loses his telepathic abilities after a surgery that removes “goo” from his sinuses.

bonuses.leadin: Five “auspicious events” occur in the lives of these people. For 10 points each:
answers: sweeping the ground [or dusting the ground, or similar]
parts: Name these people who eventually reach complete understanding, or Kevala jñāna (“KEH-val GYA-na”). 24 of these people are among the 63 illustrious people of each half-cycle.
Tirthankara (“TIER-tan-ka-ra”) are spiritual teachers of dharma in this Indian religion, which places extreme emphasis on ahimsa, or nonviolence.
In practicing ahimsa toward all living creatures, Jain monks do this action while walking in order to avoid stepping on small animals. A general English-language description is acceptable.

bonuses.leadin: A 500-page book by Nicholas Orme ("ORM") is dedicated to refuting a thesis that this class of people did not exist in the Middle Ages. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this class of people. Orme attacked Philippe Ariès’s (“ARR-ee-ez”) thesis about this class of people, which Ariès developed in a book that was the first to use them as a field of study.
Ariès studied childhood in an era with this two-word name. This period stretches from the end of the Middle Ages until the advent of political and industrial revolutions.
One proposed date for the start of the early modern period is the fall of this city to the Ottomans in 1453.

bonuses.leadin: Though not entirely red or entirely sandstone, the Old Red Sandstone is definitely old. For 10 points each:
answers: Devonian period [accept the Great Devonian Controversy; prompt on Devon]

fossiliferous [accept answers indicating that they bear fossils, have fossils in them, or are part of the fossil record] (the Lazarus effect is a fossil disappearing from the fossil record, only to reappear a long time later)
lobe-finned fish [accept bony fish, sarcopterygian, or osteichthyes; accept Age of Fishes; prompt on tetrapods or Tetrapoda]
parts: The formation starts in the Silurian and ends in the Carboniferous, spanning this geologic period. This period was devised to resolve controversy regarding the history of its namesake county in southwest England.

Despite covering large swathes of the North Atlantic, it can be difficult to date the Old Red Sandstone because it largely lacks this property due to being terrestrial. The sampling bias from only some sediments having this property produces an effect named for Lazarus. A description is acceptable.

The Devonian is often called the age of these marine animals due to their rapid diversification. Near the end of the period, Tiktaalik became the first species of these animals to walk on land with its lobed fins.

bonuses.leadin: This woman may have been the wife of the Count Hugues de Sade (“OOG de SOD”). For 10 points each:
answers: Laura [accept Laura de Noves; prompt on de Noves alone]
Dante Alighieri [accept either underlined portion; accept Durante di Alighiero degli Alighieri]
parts: Name this woman who is addressed by a poem beginning “You who hear the sound, in scattered rhymes,” part of Il Canzionere.
Laura was the love interest of this Italian poet who lends his name to a type of sonnet.

The literary critic Gianfranco Contini contrasted Petrarch’s “monolinguismo” with this other Italian poet’s “plurilinguismo,” which he demonstrated in his collections Le Rime (“lay REE-may”) and La Vita Nuova.

bonuses.leadin: An American version of this sitcom aired its first season on CBS in 2021, swapping the pants-less MP Julian Sutcliffe for Trevor, a pants-less Wall Street trader. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sitcom starring Charlotte Ritchie as a young woman who discovers that she has inherited the crumbling Button Manor and decides to renovate it, to the displeasure of its occupants.

The creators of Ghosts came to prominence as members of a comedy troupe named for "horrible" stories in this genre. A Comedy Central show features drunk people telling stories in this genre, and Dan Carlin hosts a podcast about "hardcore" stories in this genre.
Charlotte Ritchie also voiced Gloria in Bravely Default 2, a 2021 game published by this studio, which was formed when two rivals merged in 2003.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the use of natural language processing methods in the humanities, for 10 points each:
parts: NLP has often been used in studies of these collections. These collections are large, structured bodies of real-world text analyzed in linguistics; when further parsed they may be referred to as treebanks.
This analytical technique determines the polarity of a set of words. This technique is often used to classify open-ended reviews as "positive" or "negative."
A popular corpus for data mining is the text of this author's books, such as Mansfield Park and Emma.

bonuses.leadin: This tsar installed the Greek bishop Ignatius as the second Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia. For 10 points each:
answers: False Dmitry I [or Pseudo-Demetrius I or the first false Dmitry; prompt on False Dmitry or Pseudo-Demetrius]
Ivan the Terrible [or Ivan IV; or Ivan Grozny; prompt on Ivan]
parts: Name this tsar. He converted to Catholicism to win support from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and was killed ten days after he married a non-Orthodox woman amidst rumors he was planning to reunite the Orthodox Church and the Papacy.
This prior tsar spread rumors that the false Dmitry was a commoner. This tsar was the first non-Rurikid tsar, and his death precipitated the Time of Troubles.
The last Rurikid tsar, Fyodor the Bellringer, was the son of this tsar. Scholars have speculated that Fyodor's timid nature is due to growing up with this fearsome ruler as a father.

bonuses.leadin: Ellie Mannette was credited with creating the modern version of this instrument which has a “ping pong” variety. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this instrument played by the Desperados and the Renegades in the annual Panorama music competition.
Tony Williams developed a soprano steelpan known as the “spider’s web pan” which had the notes arranged according to the “circle” of this interval, the gap between C and G.
Ralph Macdonald, who wrote the hit songs “Where Is the Love” and “Just the Two Of Us”, came to fame playing the steelpan for this musician who released the 1956 album Calypso.

bonuses.leadin: Jean Nicolet (“John nee-ko-LAY”), the first European to visit Wisconsin, was one of a set of people described by this term. For 10 points each:
answers: coureur de bois [or coureurs des bois; prompt on runner of the woods]
Lewis and Clark expedition [or the Corps of Discovery expedition] (Charbonneau's wife was Sacagawea.)
parts: Give this French-language term for traders in what is now the Northern United States and Canada. These unlicensed traders would canoe great distances into the interior to trade with First Nations peoples.
Coureurs des bois (“COOR-er day BWAH”) primarily traded these goods, which made up most of the economy of frontier Canada. Some coureurs des bois would also trap animals to make these goods.
The coureur de bois Toussaint Charbonneau (“too-SAN char-bo-NO”) aided this expedition after meeting it at Fort Mandan, although his wife needed to save him when he nearly capsized his boat.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about unusual museums:
parts: This museum in Boston displays collections from almost entirely anonymous artists. This museum’s submission guidelines require “genuine intent,” and displays pieces with tongue-in-cheek titles and descriptions.
The Cancún (“can-COON”) Museum of Art has this unusual characteristic. Due to this characteristic, some of the heavier sculptures are installed using lift bags to avoid killing the exhibit designers.
An Indonesian museum is dedicated to historical standards for this concept, such as foot binding and lip discs. Taste and this concept are the subjects of aesthetics.

bonuses.leadin: This process is mediated by a namesake “-some” (“ZOHM”), which may contain pyrin (“PIE-rin”) domains and respond to expression of caspases (“CASS-paces”). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process, which culminates in the release of cytokines like IL-18. Cells involved in this aspect of innate immunity may undergo pyroptosis (“pie-rop-TOE-sis”) in response to pathogen- or danger-associated molecular patterns.
This class of compounds is an important family of PAMPs (“pamps”) detected by TLR4. These molecules are the prototypical endotoxins, as they form part of the cell wall in Gram-negative bacteria.

On a macroscopic level, inflammation produces this symptom as one of the five cardinal signs. This symptom is usually assessed using subjective scales which might assign a one to a stubbed toe and a nine to eating nails.

bonuses.leadin: The brass section plays a jazzy riff as the vocalists cry out “let’s go!” in this song. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this song with the repeated lyric “I’m ‘bout to buy Las Vegas after this roll.” This song, which is named for a favorable outcome at a casino, comes before “Skate” in the tracklist of a November 2021 album.

“777” (“seven-seven-seven”) is a song from An Evening with Silk Sonic, a fusion album by Anderson .Paak (“pack”) and this other singer. His solo work includes the album 24K Magic (“24-karat magic”) and singles like “Just the Way You Are”
Another song on An Evening with Silk Sonic is “After Last Night,” which features this pop bassist. This man’s Grammy-winning album It Is What It Is features his single “Dragonball Durag” (“dew-rag”).

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about sculptures that have become popular on the internet:
parts: A Japanese sculpture with a distorted smile and fish-like eyes is associated with this “challenge” hoax, which claimed that a namesake character was showing up on YouTube Kids videos and telling children to harm themselves.

A sculpture resembling an elephant seal has become bizarrely popular in this country. A plush of the sculpture, nicknamed “Pochekun,” ("POH-chay-koon") was photographed among empty seats in this country’s parliament to represent the people waiting for the government to act.
The “Stoned Fox” meme, in which a frazzled-looking fox sits in a chair and stares into space, is a piece in this medium. Pieces in this medium are dead animals that are stuffed and posed.

bonuses.leadin: Sīmǎ Qiān's (“SEE-ma CHEN’s”) father, Sīmǎ Tán, was the first to use the common term for this philosophy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this governing philosophy which seeks to use a carefully designed system of incentives and punishments to control a country. Hán Fēi's promotion of this philosophy influenced the rule of Qín Shǐ Huáng (“chin shee hwong”).

This dynasty's Emperor Wu incorporated many Legalist principles into his administration, during which the size of this dynasty nearly doubled. This dynasty names the major ethnic group of mainland China.

Emperor Wu also conducted wars with these nomadic people who raided northern China. The leader of these people was called chanyu, and their relationship to other later steppe people is currently unknown.

bonuses.leadin: A fish of this color obscures the left side of the subject’s face in An Englishman In Moscow. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this color frequently seen in the backgrounds of paintings by El Lissitzky. A square of this color is aligned diagonally on the top-right of an abstract painting currently on view in the MoMA.
White on White is a work by Kazimir Malevich as part of this Russian abstract art movement, named for the pure artistic feeling of seeing colors on a canvas.
Lissitzky and Malevich were members of this Suprematist art group, whose seal was Malevich’s work Black Square. This group’s name is a Russian shortening of the phrase “Champions of the New Art.”

bonuses.leadin: This poet taught Lou Reed, who dedicated the song “European Song” on The Velvet Underground and Nico to him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American poet, the dedicatee of a poem in Robert Lowell’s Life Studies. This man wrote the story“In Dreams Begin Responsibilities”.
Delmore Schwartz provided the inspiration for this 1975 Nobel Prize winning author’s novel Humboldt's Gift about the relationship between Von Humbolt Fleischer and Charlie Citrine.

In Humboldt’s Gift, Fleischer makes a small fortune selling a Harlequin collection of these poems, Delmore Schwartz wrote one of these poems about the “children of the czar”. Alfred Noyes's "The Highwayman" is another of these poems.

bonuses.leadin: University of Chicago chancellor Robert Zimmer and hack psychologist Steven Pinker recently announced they were stepping down from the advisory board of this university. For 10 points each:
answers: University of Austin [or UATX; do not accept or prompt on "University of Texas at Austin"]
parts: Name this university, founded in 2021 as a counter to the prevailing liberalism and "cancel culture" of the American university. It is named for the city in Texas where it will eventually be located.

Bari Weiss, who announced the formation of the University of Austin on her Substack, also wrote a 2018 New York Times profile of figures in this "anti-cancel culture" movement such as Eric Weinstein and Sam Harris.

The Weiss profile also identified this former Breitbart editor and current conservative podcaster as a member of the intellectual dark web. He is known for emphasizing his use of "facts and logic" to own liberals.
